Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story: I had just moved into my new apartment, and the excitement of starting fresh was still buzzing in my chest. I baked a small cake, hoping to break the ice with my neighbors. As I stepped into the hallway, cake in hand, I spotted Mrs. Kim from next door. She smiled, and I smiled back, ready to introduce myself and offer a slice. But my phone buzzed—my telemarketing shift was starting. I ducked back inside, balancing the cake and my headset, and dialed the first number on my list. The customer on the other end immediately launched into a barrage of technical questions about the new service. My script only covered the basics, and I could feel my voice faltering as I tried to sound confident. At the same time, I heard a gentle knock—Mrs. Kim, probably wondering if I was still coming by. I felt torn, wanting to be the friendly neighbor everyone expects, but also needing to handle the call professionally, as my supervisor demanded. My heart pounded as I stared at the cake, headset pressing into my ear, caught between two worlds and unsure which to choose.
